channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Veterans of Ukraine’s Revolution Recall Violence in Kiev
item.description: Some veterans of Kiev’s Independence Square are healing abroad, physically and mentally, from the bloody protests that helped topple Ukraine’s president.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Ben Kilb for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuri Kravchuk at a hospital in Germany. He is one of dozens of injured Ukrainian protesters sent to nations across Europe to heal.

item.title: Searchers Investigating Underwater Signals in Hunt for Jet
item.description: Chinese and Australian vessels were said to have detected signals three times, but there was no confirmed link to the missing Malaysia Airlines jet.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE
item.media:description: This Chinese patrol ship, the Haixun 01, reported Saturday that an underwater sensor had picked up a promising signal.

item.title: Ship Reports Getting Signal That Could Be Black Box of Missing Jet
item.description: Australian authorities said that they were investigating reports by ships in the search flotilla that underwater sensors had picked up signals that could be from the plane’s data and voice recorders.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE
item.media:description: This Chinese patrol ship, the Haixun 01, reported Saturday that an underwater sensor had picked up a promising signal.

item.title: Full Government of Mali Resigns; Premier Is Named
item.description: A town planning minister, Moussa Mara, will become prime minister, a presidential spokesman said on state television late on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Brazil Sends In Armed Forces to Assist in Policing Poor Area
item.description: The operation is a part of a five-year-old “pacification” policing program, which has established permanent police patrols in select slums in Rio de Janeiro ahead of this year’s World Cup tournament.
item.dc:creator: By TAYLOR BARNES
item.media:description: A soldier patrolled Complexo da Maré in Rio de Janeiro on Saturday in an effort to improve security and drive out drug gangs.

item.title: Lawyer Sees No Revenge in an Arrest in New Delhi
item.description: The lawyer for a New York police officer arrested in India for having three rounds of ammunition said that there was no connection between the case and the arrest of an Indian diplomat in New York last year.
item.dc:creator: By EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Election in Hungary Tests Nation’s Tilt to the Right
item.description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban and his coalition appear headed for victory when Hungarians vote on Sunday, but the election will gauge the depth of voters’ support and their interest in pushing the nation further right.
item.dc:creator: By PALKO KARASZ and ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban at a rally in Budapest last month. His coalition led in opinion polls.

item.title: Citizenship-for-Cash Program in Malta Stirs Security Concerns in European Union
item.description: Opponents said the program, under which foreigners can pay to buy Maltese citizenship, could open the door to the West for criminals or terrorists.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Break in Syrian War Brings Brittle Calm
item.description: Beneath a calm imposed by military force, siege and starvation, the stage appears set for an unstable period of prolonged conflict that could explode again in months or years.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Delays in Effort to Refocus C.I.A. From Drone War
item.description: Despite avowals about the need to refocus the agency on its original missions of analysis, intelligence collecting and espionage, the paramilitary operations have proven hard to give up.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI
item.media:description: John O. Brennan, the director of the C.I.A., took questions after addressing the Council on Foreign Relations last month.

item.title: Blast Near Falluja Kills 17 Iraq Troops
item.description: The soldiers, part of an army convoy patrolling Albu Hadeed, near Falluja, were attacked by gunmen from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria militant group, security officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Clan Fighting in Egypt Kills at Least 23
item.description: Officials said the fighting in Aswan Province erupted over the harassment of a girl, and students from the two sides later sprayed offensive graffiti at a local school.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Apathy and Fear of Taliban Combine to Keep Rural Voters Away From the Polls
item.description: In districts where the insurgency is strongest, the Taliban did not have to pick up rifles to disrupt the vote.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: U.N. Leader Urges Action in Central African Republic
item.description: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, called on the Security Council to authorize a peacekeeping force of 12,000 to try to halt sectarian violence in the Central African Republic.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Thais Rally in Support of Beleaguered Prime Minister
item.description: The government supporters said they were prepared to thwart any move to dismiss Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, who faces mounting legal cases that could lead to her removal from office in coming weeks.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: Supporters of Thailand’s government marched Saturday on the western outskirts of Bangkok.

item.title: The Lede: Iran’s Reformers Include More Than One Former Hostage-Taker
item.description: Hostage-takers who became leading reformers in Iran include the man who devised the plan to seize the United States Embassy in Tehran in 1979 and the woman who explained the group’s demands to foreign reporters.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A recent image of Hamid Aboutalebi from Iran's Khabar Online.

item.title: Afghan Turnout Is High as Voters Defy the Taliban
item.description: The election will mark the first time Afghans have changed their leader at the polls in modern history as Hamid Karzai’s dozen years in power end.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND, AZAM AHMED and MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: DealBook: Vivendi Chooses to Sell Mobile Phone Unit to Altice, Ending Noisy Bidding War
item.description: Under the deal, which is subject to regulatory approval, Vivendi will receive €13.5 billion when the transaction is completed and a later potential payment of €750 million.
item.dc:creator: By CHAD BRAY

item.title: 2 Italian Priests and a Canadian Nun Are Abducted in Cameroon
item.description: The three were said to be taken by “unknown people” who broke open the doors of their residences in an area near the Nigerian border that is known for kidnappings.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: U.S. Response to Crimea Worries Japan’s Leaders
item.description: The failure of the United States to take more forceful action to help Ukraine leaves Japan concerned about whether Washington would aid it in a conflict with China.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER and MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: World Briefing: Uganda: Police Raid U.S.-Financed Health Project
item.description: Police officers raided the offices of an American-financed project that offers services to AIDS patients, a government spokesman said Friday, in what appeared to be the first public action to enforce a new anti-homosexuality law.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: At War Blog: We Were Just Laughing: Days With Anja Niedringhaus and Kathy Gannon
item.description: A reporter who was recently with Anja Niedringhaus and Kathy Gannon of The Associated Press, longtime fellow chroniclers of events in Afghanistan, reflects on the attack on them and the changing environment in the country.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: The photographer Anja Niedringhaus at a swimming event at the 2004 Olympic Games in Athens.

item.title: Judge Dismisses Suit Against Administration Officials Over Drone Strikes
item.description: A federal judge ruled that courts should hesitate before holding a government official personally responsible for violating a citizen’s rights in the context of a wartime action.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: French Push U.N. to Seek War Crimes Case in Syria
item.description: The French have taken the first steps toward a Security Council referral of Syrians suspected of war crimes to the International Criminal Court.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Covering Afghan Vote, Until Shot by an Ally
item.description: Anja Niedringhaus, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer for The Associated Press, was attacked in eastern Afghanistan as she traveled to cover preparations for the presidential vote.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and FAROOQ JAN MANGAL
